Level 3 maths and English

Level 3 maths and English payment breakdown on a 1 year programme
Level 3 maths and English payment

Supports delivery of maths and English to students on substantial level 3 study programmes (including T Levels) who have not yet attained a grade 9 to 4 GCSE or equivalent in either or both of these subjects

 Payment per subject Instances Total funded students Sub-total
Students on a 1 year eligible programme (less than 18 months) £375 0 111 £0
Students on a 2 year eligible programme (18 months or more) £750 0 111 £0
Total level 3 maths and English payment £0

A student will attract an instance of funding for each subject in which they do not hold a GCSE grade 9 to 4 or equivalent at the start of their level 3 programme. Those without English or without maths will receive one instance and those without English and without maths will receive 2 instances.

More about level 3 maths and English payment (opens in new tab)

Where average instances comes from

Average instances are calculated using data from the October 2020 return (R14). A student gets one instance of funding if they do not have grade 4, C or higher in GCSE maths or English. Those without both GCSEs get 2 instances of funding.

Where places comes from

Places come from the Mid Year (R06) Funding Claim 2020 to 2021 or your local authority agreed it with ESFA. This provides a base level of funding.

You must agree additional funding above this level with your local authority. Local authorities pay you the top-up funding directly. It is not shown in this statement.

More about amendments to high needs places (opens in new tab)

Discretionary bursary fund 2021 to 2022 {% if scenario == '1' %}£261,562.80{% elif scenario == '2' %}£381,008.70{% else %}£10,785{% endif %}
More about this table

The sub-total for each discretionary bursary element is calculated by multiplying the number of students by the instances per student to get the number of instances:

Total funded students × Instances per student = Number of instances

The number of instances is then multiplied by the rate:

Number of instances × Rate = Sub-total

The sub-totals are then added together to make your discretionary bursary fund total. This figure is then used in the next calculation. It is compared with your total discretionary bursary fund from 2019 to 2020. It will be adjusted if it falls outside the limits set for this year.

How instances are calculated (opens in new tab)

More about the 16 to 19 bursary fund (opens in new tab)
Where free meals adjustment comes from

The free meals adjustment figure corrects historic double funding between free meals and the bursary fund. We calculate your share of the total number of students supported with free meals and then work out how much should be subtracted from your discretionary bursary allocation.

Rounding differences in your calculations

The values in this statement may not add up precisely to the totals provided due to rounding. The calculation of your funding is done using actual values.

Discretionary bursary fund 2021 to 2022 £10,785
Adjusted discretionary bursary fund £9,540
More about this table

The bursary has been adjusted because this year's discretionary bursary figure is outside the baseline limits.

From 2020 to 2021, we moved to a new methodology to calculate your discretionary bursary fund.

In 2019 to 2020, you received the amount shown in the first row of the adjusted discretionary bursary fund table. Going forward:

  • In 2020 to 2021, you received an amount capped between +/- 25% of the 2019 to 2020 total
  • This year, you will receive an amount capped between +/- 50% of the 2019 to 2020 total
  • In 2022 to 2023, you will receive an amount capped between +/- 75% of the 2019 to 2020 total
  • 2023 to 2024 onward - you receive the amount with no cap applied
More about the 16 to 19 bursary fund (opens in new tab)
